content.description: Start below the ramp and follow smaller than expected features up the ramp to a comfortable stance below the headwall. Work your way up the left wall and into the notch, from which you can top out. Beware of a few hollow sounding jugs near the top.
content.protection:
Single rack with some smaller size pieces. There are no top anchors or bolts on this route. However, the Mighty Dog anchors are located near the top out and it is possible to use them as a belay with appropriate rigging.  

  The climbing team may need to give careful consideration to anchoring in the belayer at the base of the route, depending on where the belayer is positioned.
content.location: Located below Mighty Dog Wall. To the left of Central Ramp.

content.description: This solo scramble climbs the exposed and unprotected Southeastern Ridge of Turkey Peak. Walk off using the hikers trail found on the West side.
content.protection: None. No bolts or top anchors. I did not notice any opportunities for  pro that would offer meaningful protection. Not suitable for Top roping or rappelling.
content.location: Found on the Southeastern side of Turkey Peak

content.description: Turkey Hooks is a fun climb up a short, right facing dihedral.  Work up the dihedral past three bolts to a small, left angling ramp about 3/4 of the way up.  The crux is the transition from the dihedral onto the ramp which requires a couple of thin moves on the face that lead to the ramp.  Pass one more bolt en route to the anchors.  The anchors are set a little ways back from the top of the route, so it is best to rap the route or use long slings if you want to top rope.
content.protection: Four quickdraws and long slings for the 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: Turkey Hooks is one of the four routes on the southwest facing wall.  It starts off of a large, sloping ledge just to the right of the Central Ramp.

content.description:
A great climb in a beautiful position. 

  Ascend the left side of the face past a horizontal break, and up the arete to the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor   (the first bolt is a bit high)
content.location: There are two major ramps on the side of Turkey peak.  Left of these locate a sheer wall facing the road.     Mighty dog climbs the left arete.

content.description: This ramp is often used by rappellers and boy scouts. Sometimes used as convenient, but exposed access to the top. Not much of a climb really.
content.protection: Double bolted rap anchors are found on top. No other bolts.
content.location: The obvious ramp to the climber's left of the bolted climbs found on Turkey Peak

content.description: The face climb has several thin moves.  The crux comes after the third bolt where the holds are very thin prior to a jug near the anchors.
content.protection: Butterfingers shares the first three bolts of Turkey Hooks, then goes straight up to the anchors.  No gear required.
content.location: The route is the face to the right of Turkey Hooks dihedral.  Just follow the bolts straight up to the anchors.  A toprope can be set by following the gulley to the left (low 5th class) to the top.

content.description: Butter Ball is located about twenty-five feet right of the Central Ramp, starts off a large, sloping ledge, and climbs the right side of the southwest face. This is the second bolted line on the main wall, to the right of Turkey Hooks/Butterfingers. Climb the vertical face on using deep, in cut holds that appear just when you need them. The climb is pretty sustained with a crux about 2/3 of the way up the route (thin face moves). Like Turkey Hooks, the anchors are set a way back from the wall. There is an annoying flake that makes rappelling or lowing hard on your rope best just to walk off. Requires long slings or webbing/cord to top rope. Good route, too bad it's so short.
content.protection: Three bolts, long slings for the 2-bolt anchor.

content.description: Turkey Peak is the tall, sloping peak east of the Main Dome and due south of Freshman Mountain.  It immediately attracts your attention because unlike all of the other formations in the park, Turkey Peak is not a dome, but an actual peak.  Considered to be the oldest rock anywhere in the park, it has a completely different feel and type of climbing than the other areas.  All of the climbing (ten routes from 5.4 to 5.12a) is found high on the south-southwest face which makes the climbing here feel a little exposed.  As you approach the park entrance, you can look to the right and see if anyone is on the wall.  This is a great area early morning area in the summer (when itÂ’s in the shade) or winter afternoon area (sun and protected from the wind).  The top of the peak can be reached by scrambling up the northwest side, or by climbing the Central Ramp route at 5.4.  The Central Ramp route also serves as a good landmark separating the Mighty Dog Wall from the southwest face.
